author: sky.cactus
content: Is this the channel for stateless Ethereum now?

author: sky.cactus
content: Has the concern of block size growth been brought up with stateless Ethereum?

author: sky.cactus
content: While we would be able to get state size to basically zero with stateless Ethereum, I feel like we may end up with block size growing by more than we gain, thus not really solving the problem of storage requirements.

author: pipermerriam
content: In general, Blocks are easier to store deal with  than the state

author: sky.cactus
content: Why is that?  Just because they can be thrown onto a spinning disk and forgotten about other than when people want to sync?

author: sky.cactus
content: I suppose with stateless Ethereum a client doesn't actually need all of history?  They can acquire latest block hash from a trusted source and then immediately start syncing/validating/mining.  You only need historic blocks if you are *trying* to build an archive node or a stateful node, which most people won't need in the stateless world.

author: sky.cactus
content: That same client can also throw away old blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: This combined with Nethermind's data marketplace (or similar) would leave us in a health spot in terms of censorship resistance, while making it so the vast majority of people wouldn't retain anything but perhaps the last 100 blocks or so.

author: sky.cactus
content: OK, I have convinced myself that stateless Ethereum is a good thing.

author: sky.cactus
content: Do we have a roadmap to stateless Ethereum?  I know it requires at least code merklization which I think is currently in R&D, but what else is necessary?

author: .vbuterin
content: binary tries, code merklization, EIP 2929, another gas change EIP to cover code usage (eg. 500 gas per chunk of code that execution ever touches)

author: .vbuterin
content: that's what I can think of on the consensus side

author: pipermerriam
content: Chain history can be loosely modeled as an append only file.  Ethereum state can effectively be modeled as a growing file that has random insertions, modification, and deletions.  It's a lot easier to do the append only file.
